001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure;
002
003/**
004 * Some alternative approximations to sin(), cos(), asin(), acos(), and atan2(), including the option to measure
005 * most values in turns instead of radians (where 1 turn equals 2pi radians). The convention here is to have methods
006 * that take input in turns or produce output in turns use a {@code _} suffix, like {@link #sin_(double)}, for turns to
007 * never be returned as a negative value but for negative turn inputs to be accepted, and for the output type to match
008 * the input type (float input gives float output, double input gives double output).
009 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 8/6/2019.
010 */
011public class MathTools {
012
013    /**
014     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
015     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
016     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
017     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
018     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
019     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
020     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
021     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
022     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
023     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
024     * potentially higher errors, though.
025     * <br>
026     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin(float)}, so you should
027     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
028     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
029     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
030     * and likewise for doubles.
031     * <br>
032     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
033     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
034     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
035     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
036     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
037     */
038
039    public static double sin(double radians)
040    {
041        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
042        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
043        radians -= floor;
044        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
045        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
050     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
051     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
052     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
053     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
054     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
055     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
056     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
057     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
058     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
059     * potentially higher errors, though.
060     * <br>
061     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos(float)}, so you should
062     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
063     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
064     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
065     * and likewise for doubles.
066     * <br>
067     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
068     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
069     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
070     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
071     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
072     */
073    public static double cos(double radians)
074    {
075        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814 + 1.0;
076        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
077        radians -= floor;
078        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
079        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
080    }
081
082    /**
083     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
084     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
085     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
086     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
087     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
088     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
089     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
090     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
091     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
092     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
093     * potentially higher errors, though.
094     * <br>
095     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
096     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
097     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
098     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
099     * and likewise for doubles.
100     * <br>
101     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
102     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
103     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
104     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
105     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
106     */
107    public static float sin(float radians)
108    {
109        radians *= 0.6366197723675814f;
110        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
111        radians -= floor;
112        radians *= 2f - radians;
113        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
114    }
115
116    /**
117     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
118     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
119     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
120     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
121     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
122     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
123     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
124     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
125     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
126     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
127     * potentially higher errors, though.
128     * <br>
129     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
130     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
131     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
132     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
133     * and likewise for doubles.
134     * <br>
135     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
136     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
137     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
138     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
139     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
140     */
141    public static float cos(float radians)
142    {
143        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814f + 1f;
144        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
145        radians -= floor;
146        radians *= 2f - radians;
147        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
148    }
149    /**
150     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
151     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX, you should
152     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sinDeg() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
153     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
154     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes one angle in degrees,
155     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
156     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
157     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
158     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
159     * all points between -360 and 360, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
160     * potentially higher errors, though.
161     * <br>
162     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
163     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
164     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
165     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
166     * and likewise for doubles.
167     * <br>
168     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
169     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
170     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
171     * @param degrees an angle in degrees as a float, often from 0 to 360, though not required to be.
172     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
173     */
174    public static float sinDegrees(float degrees)
175    {
176        degrees = degrees * 0.011111111111111112f;
177        final int floor = (degrees >= 0.0 ? (int) degrees : (int) degrees - 1) & -2;
178        degrees -= floor;
179        degrees *= 2f - degrees;
180        return degrees * (-0.775f - 0.225f * degrees) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
181    }
182
183    /**
184     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
185     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX, you should
186     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cosDeg() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
187     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
188     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes one angle in degrees,
189     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
190     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
191     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
192     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
193     * all points between -360 and 360, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
194     * potentially higher errors, though.
195     * <br>
196     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
197     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
198     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
199     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
200     * and likewise for doubles.
201     * <br>
202     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
203     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
204     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
205     * @param degrees an angle in degrees as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
206     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
207     */
208    public static float cosDegrees(float degrees)
209    {
210        degrees = degrees * 0.011111111111111112f + 1f;
211        final int floor = (degrees >= 0.0 ? (int) degrees : (int) degrees - 1) & -2;
212        degrees -= floor;
213        degrees *= 2f - degrees;
214        return degrees * (-0.775f - 0.225f * degrees) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
215    }
216    
217    /**
218     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
219     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
220     * to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
221     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
222     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
223     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
224     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
225     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
226     * <br>
227     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin_(float)}, so you should
228     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
229     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
230     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
231     * and likewise for doubles.
232     * <br>
233     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
234     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
235     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
236     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
237     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
238     */
239    public static double sin_(double turns)
240    {
241        turns *= 4.0;
242        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
243        turns -= floor;
244        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
245        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
246    }
247
248    /**
249     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
250     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
251     * to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
252     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
253     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
254     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
255     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
256     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
257     * <br>
258     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(float)}, so you should
259     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
260     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
261     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
262     * and likewise for doubles.
263     * <br>
264     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
265     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
266     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
267     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
268     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
269     */
270    public static double cos_(double turns)
271    {
272        turns = turns * 4.0 + 1.0;
273        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
274        turns -= floor;
275        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
276        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
277    }
278
279    /**
280     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
281     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
282     * building block for other measurements; to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to
283     * 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
284     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
285     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
286     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
287     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
288     * method).
289     * <br>
290     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin_(double)}, so you should
291     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
292     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
293     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
294     * and likewise for doubles.
295     * <br>
296     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
297     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
298     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
299     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
300     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
301     */
302    public static float sin_(float turns)
303    {
304        turns *= 4f;
305        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
306        turns -= floor;
307        turns *= 2f - turns;
308        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
309    }
310
311    /**
312     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
313     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
314     * building block for other measurements; to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal
315     * to 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
316     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
317     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
318     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
319     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
320     * method).
321     * <br>
322     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(double)}, so you should
323     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
324     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
325     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
326     * and likewise for doubles.
327     * <br>
328     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
329     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
330     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
331     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
332     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
333     */
334    public static float cos_(float turns)
335    {
336        turns = turns * 4f + 1f;
337        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
338        turns -= floor;
339        turns *= 2f - turns;
340        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
341    }
342
343    /**
344     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
345     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
346     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
347     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
348     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
349     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
350     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
351     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
352     * handy information that makes this approach usable. This method changed from an earlier
353     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
354     * {@link #atan2_(double, double)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
355     * that method returns an angle from 0.0 (equal to 0 degrees) to 1.0 (equal to 360 degrees).
356     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
357     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
358     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double; ranges from -PI to PI
359     */
360    public static double atan2(double y, double x)
361    {
362        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
363        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
364        boolean invert = ay > ax;
365        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
366        z = ((((0.141499  * z) - 0.343315 ) * z - 0.016224 ) * z + 1.003839 ) * z - 0.000158 ;
367        if (invert) z = 1.5707963267948966 - z;
368        if (x < 0) z = 3.141592653589793 - z;
369        return Math.copySign(z, y);
370    }
371
372    /**
373     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
374     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
375     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
376     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
377     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
378     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
379     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
380     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
381     * handy information that makes this approach usable. This method changed from an earlier
382     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
383     * {@link #atan2_(float, float)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
384     * that method returns an angle from 0f (equal to 0 degrees) to 1f (equal to 360 degrees).
385     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
386     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
387     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float; ranges from -PI to PI
388     */
389    public static float atan2(float y, float x) {
390        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
391        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
392        boolean invert = ay > ax;
393        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
394        z = ((((0.141499f * z) - 0.343315f) * z - 0.016224f) * z + 1.003839f) * z - 0.000158f;
395        if (invert) z = 1.5707963267948966f - z;
396        if (x < 0) z = 3.141592653589793f - z;
397        return Math.copySign(z, y);
398    }
399
400    /**
401     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as 
402     * doubles and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 1.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
403     * equivalent to 360 degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians,
404     * or by {@code 360f} to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles. Will never return a
405     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
406     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
407     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
408     * handy information that makes this approach usable. Note that
409     * {@link #atan2(double, double)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
410     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
411     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
412     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
413     * @return the angle to the given point, as a double from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive
414     */
415    public static double atan2_(double y, double x)
416    {
417        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
418        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
419        boolean invert = ay > ax;
420        double z = invert ? ax/ay : ay/ax;
421        z = (((((0.022520265292560102) * z) - (0.054640279287594046)) * z - (0.0025821297967229097)) * z + (0.1597659389184251)) * z - (0.000025146481008519463);
422        if(invert) z = 0.25 - z;
423        if(x < 0) z = 0.5 - z;
424        return y < 0 ? (int)(1+z) - z : z;
425
426    }
427    /**
428     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as floats
429     * and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0f to 1.0f, with one cycle over the range equivalent to 360
430     * degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians, or by {@code 360f}
431     * to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats. Will never return a negative number, which
432     * may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
433     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
434     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
435     * handy information that makes this approach usable. Note that
436     * {@link #atan2(float, float)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
437     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
438     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
439     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
440     * @return the angle to the given point, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive
441     */
442    public static float atan2_(float y, float x)
443    {
444        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0f;
445        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
446        boolean invert = ay > ax;
447        float z = invert ? ax/ay : ay/ax;
448        z = (((((0.022520265292560102f) * z) - (0.054640279287594046f)) * z - (0.0025821297967229097f)) * z + (0.1597659389184251f)) * z - (0.000025146481008519463f);
449        if(invert) z = 0.25f - z;
450        if(x < 0) z = 0.5f - z;
451        return y < 0 ? (int)(1+z) - z : z;
452    }
453
454    /**
455     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
456     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from -180 to 180. Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
457     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
458     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
459     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
460     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
461     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
462     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
463     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
464     * <br>
465     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from 0 to 360,
466     * instead of -180 to 180, in case negative angles are undesirable.
467     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
468     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
469     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a double
470     */
471    public static double atan2Degrees(double y, double x)
472    {
473        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
474        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
475        boolean invert = ay > ax;
476        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
477        z = (((((8.107295505321636)  * z) - (19.670500543533855) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475) ) * z + (57.51573801063304) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006) ;
478        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
479        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
480        return Math.copySign(z, y);
481    }
482
483    /**
484     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
485     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from -180 to 180. Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
486     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
487     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
488     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
489     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
490     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
491     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
492     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
493     * <br>
494     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from 0 to 360,
495     * instead of -180 to 180, in case negative angles are undesirable.
496     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
497     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
498     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float
499     */
500    public static float atan2Degrees(float y, float x)
501    {
502        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
503        float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
504        boolean invert = ay > ax;
505        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
506        z = (((((8.107295505321636f)  * z) - (19.670500543533855f) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475f) ) * z + (57.51573801063304f) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006f) ;
507        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
508        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
509        return Math.copySign(z, y);
510    }
511
512    /**
513     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
514     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from 0 to 360 (both inclusive). Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
515     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
516     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
517     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
518     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
519     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
520     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
521     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
522     * <br>
523     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees(double, double)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from -180 to 180,
524     * matching {@link Math#atan2(double, double)}'s convention.
525     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
526     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
527     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a double
528     */
529    public static double atan2Degrees360(double y, double x)
530    {
531        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
532        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
533        boolean invert = ay > ax;
534        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
535        z = (((((8.107295505321636)  * z) - (19.670500543533855) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475) ) * z + (57.51573801063304) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006) ;
536        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
537        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
538        return y < 0 ? 360 - z : z;
539    }
540    /**
541     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
542     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from 0 to 360 (both inclusive). Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
543     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
544     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
545     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
546     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
547     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
548     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
549     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
550     * <br>
551     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from -180 to 180,
552     * matching {@link Math#atan2(double, double)}'s convention.
553     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
554     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
555     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float
556     */
557    public static float atan2Degrees360(float y, float x)
558    {
559        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
560        float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
561        boolean invert = ay > ax;
562        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
563        z = (((((8.107295505321636f)  * z) - (19.670500543533855f) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475f) ) * z + (57.51573801063304f) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006f) ;
564        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
565        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
566        return y < 0 ? 360 - z : z;
567    }
568
569    /**
570     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(double, double)}.
571     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's
572     * implementation). It is currently more precise than libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, but this isn't
573     * quite as fast; the difference in precision is hard to spot but can be noticeable in some usage.
574     * @param n an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
575     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
576     */
577    public static float asin(final float n)
578    {
579        final float ax = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
580        if(ax < ay)
581        {
582            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
583                    r = 1.57079637f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
584            return (n < 0f) ? -r : r;
585        }
586        else {
587            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
588                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
589            return (n < 0f) ? -r : r;
590        }
591    }
592
593    /**
594     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(float, float)}.
595     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's
596     * implementation). It is currently more precise than libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, but this isn't
597     * quite as fast; the difference in precision is hard to spot but can be noticeable in some usage.
598     * @param n an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
599     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
600     */
601    public static double asin(final double n)
602    {
603        final double ax = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
604        if(ax < ay)
605        {
606            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
607                    r = 1.57079637 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
608            return (n < 0.0) ? -r : r;
609        }
610        else {
611            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
612                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
613            return (n < 0.0) ? -r : r;
614        }
615    }
616    /**
617     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(double, double)}.
618     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's
619     * implementation). It is currently more precise than libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, but this isn't
620     * quite as fast; the difference in precision is hard to spot but can be noticeable in some usage.
621     * @param n an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
622     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
623     */
624    public static double acos(final double n)
625    {
626        final double ax = Math.abs(n), ay = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n);
627        if(ax < ay)
628        {
629            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
630                    r = 1.57079637 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
631            return (n < 0.0) ? Math.PI - r : r;
632        }
633        else {
634            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
635                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a);
636            return (n < 0.0) ? Math.PI - r : r;
637        }
638    }
639    /**
640     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, based on a simplified version of {@link #atan2(float, float)}.
641     * This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's
642     * implementation). It is currently more precise than libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, but this isn't
643     * quite as fast; the difference in precision is hard to spot but can be noticeable in some usage.
644     * @param n an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
645     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
646     */
647    public static float acos(final float n)
648    {
649        final float ax = Math.abs(n), ay = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n);
650        if(ax < ay)
651        {
652            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
653                    r = 1.57079637f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
654            return (n < 0f) ? 3.14159265358979323846f - r : r;
655        }
656        else {
657            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
658                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a);
659            return (n < 0.0) ? 3.14159265358979323846f - r : r;
660        }
661    }
662
663    /**
664     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
665     * range from 0.75 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.25 (inclusive).
666     * <br>
667     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
668     * @param n a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
669     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(double)}
670     */
671    public static double asin_(final double n)
672    {
673        if(n == 0.0) return 0.0;
674        final double ax = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
675        if(ax < ay)
676        {
677            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
678                    r = 0.25 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
679            return (n < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
680        }
681        else {
682            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
683                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
684            return (n < 0.0) ? 1.0 - r : r;
685        }
686    }
687    /**
688     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
689     * range from 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.5 (inclusive).
690     * <br>
691     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
692     * @param n a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
693     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(double)}
694     */
695    public static double acos_(final double n)
696    {
697        final double ax = Math.abs(n), ay = Math.sqrt(1.0 - n * n);
698        if(ax < ay)
699        {
700            final double a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
701                    r = 0.25 - (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
702            return (n < 0.0) ? 0.5 - r : r;
703        }
704        else {
705            final double a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
706                    r = (((-0.0464964749 * s + 0.15931422) * s - 0.327622764) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535;
707            return (n < 0.0) ? 0.5 - r : r;
708        }
709    }
710
711
712    /**
713     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
714     * range from 0.75f (inclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.25f
715     * (inclusive).
716     * <br>
717     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
718     * @param n a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
719     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(float)}
720     */
721    public static float asin_(final float n)
722    {
723        if(n == 0.0f) return 0.0f;
724        final float ax = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n), ay = Math.abs(n);
725        if(ax < ay)
726        {
727            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
728                    r = 0.25f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
729            return (n < 0.0f) ? 1.0f - r : r;
730        }
731        else {
732            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
733                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
734            return (n < 0.0f) ? 1.0f - r : r;
735        }
736    }
737    /**
738     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
739     * range from 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.5f (inclusive).
740     * <br>
741     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
742     * @param n a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
743     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(float)}
744     */
745    public static float acos_(final float n)
746    {
747        final float ax = Math.abs(n), ay = (float) Math.sqrt(1f - n * n);
748        if(ax < ay)
749        {
750            final float a = ax / ay, s = a * a,
751                    r = 0.25f - (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
752            return (n < 0.0f) ? 0.5f - r : r;
753        }
754        else {
755            final float a = ay / ax, s = a * a,
756                    r = (((-0.0464964749f * s + 0.15931422f) * s - 0.327622764f) * s * a + a) * 0.15915494309189535f;
757            return (n < 0.0f) ? 0.5f - r : r;
758        }
759    }
760
761    /**
762     *  Linearly interpolates between fromValue to toValue on progress position.
763     * @param fromValue starting float value; can be any finite float
764     * @param toValue ending float value; can be any finite float
765     * @param progress how far the interpolation should go, between 0 (equal to fromValue) and 1 (equal to toValue)
766     */
767    public static float lerp (final float fromValue, final float toValue, final float progress) {
768        return fromValue + (toValue - fromValue) * progress;
769    }
770
771}
